item.title: Met officer investigated over rape allegations
item.description: The serving officer was not charged but faces a misconduct hearing over alleged attacks on colleagues.

item.title: Covid-19: Few people with symptoms are self-isolating, study finds
item.description: And fewer than one in five people request a test if they have symptoms, a report on test and trace says.

item.title: Derek Chauvin trial: New footage shows George Floyd pleading with officers
item.description: George Floyd can be heard telling officers, "I'm not a bad guy" in newly-revealed bodycam footage.

item.title: Crime victims to be told when perpetrators leave prison
item.description: A new code of rights will also enable victims of rape to choose their police interviewer's gender.

item.title: Blue plaque planned to commemorate Diana, Princess of Wales
item.description: Six blue plaques for women have been announced by English Heritage to address the gender imbalance.

item.title: Assisted dying inquiry essential, leading brain surgeon says
item.description: A brain surgeon, left shocked and frightened by his cancer diagnosis, says the law needs changing.

item.title: 'Child among four dead' in shooting at office building in Orange, California
item.description: Police say the suspect was shot and wounded and the situation has now been "stabilised".

item.title: Covid vaccine manufacturers should work with poorer countries, says WTO chief
item.description: WTO head Dr Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala says the AstraZeneca deal with India is a good example.

item.title: Minimum wage rises for two million workers
item.description: Most low-paid workers will receive a pay rise, but those on furlough will miss out.

item.title: Facebook bans 'voice of Trump' from platform
item.description: An interview with the ex-president was posted by his daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, on Facebook.

item.title: Runway dining at $540 a meal proving hit in Japan
item.description: Japan's biggest airline is making the most of grounded planes while Australian carriers are cutting prices.

item.title: Tiger Woods crash: Los Angeles police determine the cause of golfer's car accident
item.description: The details of what caused Tiger Woods' car crash will only be released if the 15-time major winner gives permission for police to share their findings.

item.title: The Papers: Race report 'backlash' and Queen 'gets second jab'
item.description: Reaction to a government-commissioned report on race and the Queen's vaccine dose are among the front-page stories.

item.title: 'You can't tell victims what racism is'
item.description: What do some young black, Asian and ethnic minority people make of the latest report on race in the UK?

item.title: Nicole Thea's husband Global Boga: 'My world has been taken awayâ€™
item.description: Afrobeats artist Global Boga speaks out about losing his YouTuber wife and their baby son.

item.title: How satellite images are helping one country hand out cash
item.description: Togo has found a new way to send emergency cash to people struggling in the pandemic.

item.title: Queen makes first public appearance of 2021
item.description: She marked the centenary of the Royal Australian Air Force at Runnymede in Surrey.

item.title: Why I bought the Lil Nas X 'Satan Shoes'
item.description: With art collective MSCHF, singer Lil Nas X created a pair of pricey and controversial trainers.

item.title: Lockdown: Are people losing skills they're not using?
item.description: Psychologists are studying whether people are losing skills because of lockdown.

item.title: Covid 19: Inside the BioNTech vaccine factory in Germany
item.description: The BBC's Jenny Hill has been given access to the factory producing millions of vaccine doses per week.

item.title: Giant chocolate helicopter 'a big challenge'
item.description: Jan Hansen says the 7ft (2.1m) tall creation was "a bigger challenge than I thought".

item.title: Fisherman's Friend tycoon Doreen Lofthouse dies aged 91
item.description: Doreen Lofthouse spread the lozenge's appeal around the world but never forgot her Lancashire roots.

item.title: Batley Grammar School: Blasphemy debate leaves town 'at crossroads'
item.description: People in Batley reflect on the row over pupils being shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Why April is a big month for your finances
item.description: Lots of changes to household bills, tax and other elements of finances take place in the course of a week.

item.title: Germany and Namibia: What's the right price to pay for genocide?
item.description: Germany is set to apologise to Namibia for a genocide more than 100 years ago - and to pay an as yet unknown amount of money.

item.title: Should airports be allowed to expand?
item.description: Climate change: Should aviation be allowed to expand?

item.title: David Cameron and Greensill: What's it all about?
item.description: Why the former PM is facing calls to be investigated over his links with a controversial financier.

item.title: Dragons' Den: The hits, misses, and why investments fall through
item.description: Peter Jones and Sara Davies discuss the mechanics of the BBC One show ahead of its 18th series.

item.title: Race report: What are the key points?
item.description: 'Immigrant optimism' is praised while some anti-racist approaches face criticism by the commission.

item.title: 'I have put everything into my winery'
item.description: South Africa's winemakers hope for a brighter future after a very tough 12 months.

item.title: Mozambique: Why IS is so hard to defeat in Mozambique
item.description: The jihadists appear to be aiming to create their own self-declared "caliphate".

item.title: England 2-1 Poland: What shape are Gareth Southgate's side in?
item.description: England have started their World Cup 2022 campaign with the perfect nine points from three opening games but even this cannot disguise the fact questions remain for manager Gareth Southgate.

item.title: Brilliant? Unbelievable? Frighteningly good? 'No bad...' - understated Tierney shines again
item.description: The best player in the playground and capable of playing in Spain or Germany - Kieran Tierney draws praise after another fine Scotland showing.

item.title: Northern Ireland's qualifying hopes take hit with Bulgaria draw
item.description: Northern Ireland's World Cup qualifying hopes are dented by a disappointing 0-0 draw against Bulgaria in Belfast.

item.title: Osaka's 23-match winning streak ended by Sakkari
item.description: Naomi Osaka's 23-match winning streak comes to an end while Daniil Medvedev is also eliminated in the Miami Open quarter-finals.

item.title: Manchester City's Demi Stokes discusses race and football on The Players podcast
item.description: Demi Stokes gives her opinion on how to increase the number of mixed-race and black players in the women's game, on The Players podcast.

item.title: 'England still have a lot of work to do', says Southgate after late victory against Poland
item.description: Gareth Southgate admits England still have a lot of work to do to be a top international team despite extending their 100% record in 2022 World Cup qualifying with victory overt Poland.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a Â£5000 fine.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 30 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Naga Munchetty: Itâ€™s time to talk about race
item.description: Naga Munchetty travelled across the UK to understand what race and racism means today.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
